content.raw: What specifically do the `.ll` extensions mean? Anything specific for the 'validation' files? I thought they stood for log liklihood? If they are not log liklihood values, perhaps a better extension would be better suited such as 'tab' (or maybe 'csv'). content.raw:
I used the defined constant ```EXT_LIKELIHOOD```, which is .ll, so I thought it stood for **l**ike**l**ihood. But I could be wrong

Also, it is a 'log likelihood' in the sense that the value being recorded is log prob(e).

The .ll files log only the validation likelihood for the last recorded round (same as the train log likelihood files).

.tab is already used, to tabulate previous sets of validation likelihood as per the description on this PR. The structure is set up to mirror the way the training log likelihood is recorded.

I'll look into if it's possible to log the round of the winner in the weighted avg, but it might not be easily possible (or at least, very nice)
content.html:
I used the defined constant EXT_LIKELIHOOD, which is .ll, so I thought it stood for likelihood. But I could be wrong

Also, it is a 'log likelihood' in the sense that the value being recorded is log prob(e).

The .ll files log only the validation likelihood for the last recorded round (same as the train log likelihood files).

.tab is already used, to tabulate previous sets of validation likelihood as per the description on this PR. The structure is set up to mirror the way the training log likelihood is recorded.

I'll look into if it's possible to log the round of the winner in the weighted avg, but it might not be easily possible (or at least, very nice)

content.raw: Why `random_state` over `random_seed`? Presumably the 'random_state' comes from instance 0?
content.html: Why random_state over random_seed? Presumably the 'random_state' comes from instance 0?

content.raw:
Validation set creation occurs before any training threads are spawned, so the 'random seed' at this point is just the one set in the environment variable. So the random state doesn't technically come from 'instance 0', because 'instance 0' doesn't exist at this point yet.

It is coincidence that the random seed ultimately ends up being the same as that for the later train instance 0 though (because the seed for an instance is seed+instance #).
content.html:
Validation set creation occurs before any training threads are spawned, so the 'random seed' at this point is just the one set in the environment variable. So the random state doesn't technically come from 'instance 0', because 'instance 0' doesn't exist at this point yet.

It is coincidence that the random seed ultimately ends up being the same as that for the later train instance 0 though (because the seed for an instance is seed+instance #).

content.raw: @hoffman what do you think should happen between the interaction of `--include-coords` and `--validation-coords`? Currently `--exclude-coords` is applied to `--validation-coords` but `--include-coords` is not. `--include-coords` states that it will "limit to genomic coordinates in FILE". This is true in every case except this one. Should this include coordinates limit include validation regions? As in, if they do not intersect, there are no validation regions? Allowing to choose a subset of validation regions by altering `--include-coords`?
content.html: @hoffman what do you think should happen between the interaction of --include-coords and --validation-coords? Currently --exclude-coords is applied to --validation-coords but --include-coords is not. --include-coords states that it will "limit to genomic coordinates in FILE". This is true in every case except this one. Should this include coordinates limit include validation regions? As in, if they do not intersect, there are no validation regions? Allowing to choose a subset of validation regions by altering --include-coords?

content.raw:
After thinking about this a bit, my vote is to leave ```--include-coords``` and ```--validation-coords``` separate. Several reasons:

* Increases the complexity of the code and may slow down performance (eg requiring multiple intersections due to all the interacting coordinate parameters)
* The way ```--include-coords``` is calculated will need to be changed as either one of the following will no longer be possible: 1) held-out validation sets (if we do not remove the intersection of val/train from train set), 2) training sets and coordinate-chosen validation sets that overlap in any way (if we do force removal of the intersection of val/train from the train set). Leaving the two options separate will give users the freedom to choose the way their training sets and validation sets are related, separate of Segway
* From a user POV, having the ```--validation-coords``` you specified possibly not actually be the coordinates of your validation set due to requiring intersection with some other parameter is strange.

Any current ambiguity with the ```--help``` message could be clarified by changing the help message for both parameters to note that they are separate and don't interact. Eg ```--include-coords``` limits genomic coordinates for all tasks except validation-related ones.
content.html:
After thinking about this a bit, my vote is to leave --include-coords and --validation-coords separate. Several reasons:

  • Increases the complexity of the code and may slow down performance (eg requiring multiple intersections due to all the interacting coordinate parameters)
  • The way --include-coords is calculated will need to be changed as either one of the following will no longer be possible: 1) held-out validation sets (if we do not remove the intersection of val/train from train set), 2) training sets and coordinate-chosen validation sets that overlap in any way (if we do force removal of the intersection of val/train from the train set). Leaving the two options separate will give users the freedom to choose the way their training sets and validation sets are related, separate of Segway
  • From a user POV, having the --validation-coords you specified possibly not actually be the coordinates of your validation set due to requiring intersection with some other parameter is strange.

Any current ambiguity with the --help message could be clarified by changing the help message for both parameters to note that they are separate and don't interact. Eg --include-coords limits genomic coordinates for all tasks except validation-related ones.

content.raw: ```full_validation_output```  is a list, not a char buffer... with ```print``` the list will just be appended to file as is, but if we use ```write```, it will need to be formatted somehow (perhaps in a loop) such that all items in ```full_validation_output``` (which is a list of tuples) are on the same line in a legible format, but a newline is also appended at the end. Seemed cleaner just to leave it as ```print```

Seemed cleaner just to leave it as print
